"Uncle Vanya" To Be
Given Tonight At 8.30
The Johns Hopkins University
Playshop will present Uncle Vanya, the great Chekhov play which
is the second major production of
the current year, tonight at 8.30
Performances
in the Playshop.
will be given every night this week
including Saturday.
Included in the cast are David
Kurland, Meyer Site, S. Vannort
Chapman, Tom Pinkerton, Jr.,
Patty Singerwood, Mary Alvey,
and Helen Ascherfeld. The production has been coached by Dr. N.
Bryllion Fagin.
Tickets for the play may be obtained at the reserve desk in the
main library. Admission is seventy-five cents.

Plan Southern Trip
Will Debate Five Teams Beginning March 25; North

Chairman Names Seven To
Freshman Banquet Group
Stanley M. Finkel, Henry Gambill, Jackson Kaufman, Howard
Linkoff, Sanford Rothstein, Seymour Romanofsky, and John Royster have been appointed to the
Freshman Banquet Committee, it
was announced today.
The committee will meet tomorrow in Levering Hall at 12.20 to
discuss further plans for the banquet, which will probably be held
sometime in April. It is necessary
that the entire committee be present at the meeting.
In the future various sub-committees will be appointed to assist
in the arrangement of the program, according to William B.
Kempton, chairman of the committee.

At a meeting held in Latrobe Hall
at 12.20 yesterday the Junior Class
voted unanimously to have Hal
Kemp's orchestra to play for the annual Junior Prom to be held at the
Alcazar Ballroom on June 4 in conjunction with the June Week festivities . The contracts were ready and
signed by the committee after the
class voiced its decision.

Press Announces
Works Printed In
Regime0fDr.Ames

The debating team will debate with
the University of Cincinnati next
Thursday in room 205, Gilman Hall,
it was announced last week by Abner
Willen, president of the Debating
Council.
The Hopkins team will uphold the
affirmative tide of the question "Resolved, That the nations of the world
shall agree to prohibit the international shipment of arms and munitions." This question was debated
several weeks ago by members of
the Debating Council.
Those who will argue for the affirmative are Sylvan Garfunkel, Philip
Grossman and Abner Willen.
The annual southern trip taken by
the team will begin March 25, the
first debate being with the University
of North Carolina. The team will
then go to Emory College, Oglethorpe
University, and the University I of
Georgia. The trip will end about
April 1 with a debate against the
University of South Carolina.
The northern trip will be taken
about the same time with two debates
almost assured. Temple, University
and LaSalle University will pit teams
against the Hopkins debaters. Those
who will make this trip are James
Morrow, Phillip Grossman, Neal Potter, and Paul Zucker. Abner Willen
and Sylvan Garfunkel will represent
the Hopkins on the southern trip.
The debating team engaged Mt. St.
Mary's last night at Emittsburg.
Those who debated for the University
team were Paul Umbarger, Phillip
Grossman, Paul Zucker, and James
Morrow.

New Coach
The appointment of William Kelso
Morrill as head lacrosse coach came
as a surprise to no one. The system
of co-coaching that was originally announced would undoubtedly have been
a flop. A head coach was needed and
Dr. Morrill was the logical man.
It must be admitted that Hopkins

Our Own Pepys
February 26—
Up and amused by Mr. Edward
Reilly's remarks at a meeting to
raise funds for the appeal of the case
of Bruno Hauptman.
"I defy anyone to prove that Hauptman was even in New Jersey the
night of the kidnapping," said Reilly.
This I cannot help but feel to be a
trifle anti-climactic, the point in question having been for all practical
purposes very effectively demonstrated some few weeks back.
So away to the University for a
little, where I met with Paul who
told me that he was no longer in
love, that his ideals had been shattered, that his faith in human nature
was now a negative quantity, but
that the affair with all had been a
very •broadening experience. It was
with the greatest of difficulty'that I
explained my uncontrolable mirth at
his remarks, my own faith in human
nature, etc., having been at a very
low ebb for some time past.
I to the library for some reading
in the mechanistic and vitalistic approaches to biological phenomena
(which topic is obviously introduced
into these pages to show the extent
and magnitude of my learning).
Reading is to serve as the basis for a
debate on the subject. I am utterly
deficient in biological knowledge, but
as my fellow debater, W. D., has been
assured by a most eminent professor
of the subject, that this is an asset
and not a debit, I shall not let it
trouble me.
Interrupted by Leon bearing proudly two front pages of the American
Weekly of some time back which, he
explained, were the gift of a learned
archaeologist. I found the association
of archaelogy with Mr. Heart's journal somewhat incongrous, but did not
mention my feeling to Leon for fear
of offending him.
So home, and to bed early to escape the talk of a friend of the family. He is the °illy man of my acquaintance in the State who can carry on
an involved conversation by himself
with ease. His remarks are invariably limited to the war (which he
fought from a chair in his club), the
"Yellow Peril" (which he sees
through the eyes of the equally yellow journals), and the decay of our
youth on which I am inclined to believe he has no information at all,
having been born in his present senility.

NEWSETTES

cDEAF'DUMB AND 'BLIN'D

"KATIE, THE KITZBUEHEL COQUETTE"—The return of the Prince
of Wales to England after a vacation
abroad was the occasion for the introduction of many new songs
throughout Britain. It so happened
that the heir to the British throne
had spent his holiday in Austria, Germany, Hungary, and France, particularly at Kitzbuehel.

By HAROLD M. KROPMAN

One song in particular "I'm Katie,
the Kitzbuehel Coquette" bids fair to
become one of Britain's most popular
songs, though not meant to reflect on
England's fair sex.
HARVARD vs. YALE—A good sized
riot was almost started at the NBC
studios last Thursday afternoon when
an announcer stepped into a room in
which the Yale Glee Club was rehearsing for the Rudy Vallee program and naively inquired:
"Pardon me, but is this the Harvard Glee Club?"

At this time, when the Home Concert, and Dance are soon to be presented by the Musical Club, marking
the end of a very successful season,
I think it is only just and proper to
see exactly who has been responsible
for all the terrible—hard work. There
is Carson Frailey, president, who
hates the noise of bombs and dice;
John Murphy, vice-president, who
thinks the most of wine, women, and
song as evidenced by his behavior on
the Atlantic City trip; Lou Reuling,
junior business manager, who leans
toward crooning as an art and accomplishment; and Harry Beck, business manager, who always makes the
announcements to the NEWS-LETTER.

At the regular meeting of the class
in camp counseling to be held tomorrow at 4.15 p. m. in Gilman 312, William S. Lilly III, director of athletics
at the Baltimore Polytechnic Institute, will be the speaker.
The night class will be addressed
by Reuben Baer, head of the counseling course, who will speak on "The
Counselor." The class will take place
at 7 p. in. in Gilman 205. Visitors are
welcome.

Aviation Club Plans To
Reorganize Completely
A complete reorganization of club
program and activities will be effected at the next meeting ef the
Aviation Club to be held Wednesday,
March 6, at 4 p. m. in the Student
Activities office.
During the meeting Grahame Duce,
president of the club, will present for
examination 150 photos of hereto unphotographed United States military
aircraft. All members are urged to
attend the meeting.

The Johns Hopkins University
Playshop will present Uncle Vanya, the great Chekhov play which
is the second major production of
the current year, tonight at 8.30
Performances
in the Playshop.
will be given every night this week

Chapman, Tom Pinkerton, Jr.,
Patty Singerwood, Mary Alvey,

Stanley M. Finkel, Henry Gambill, Jackson Kaufman, Howard
Linkoff, Sanford Rothstein, Seymour Romanofsky, and John Royster have been appointed to the
Freshman Banquet Committee, it
was announced today.
The committee will meet tomorrow in Levering Hall at 12.20 to
discuss further plans for the banquet, which will probably be held
sometime in April. It is necessary
that the entire committee be present at the meeting.
In the future various sub-committees will be appointed to assist
in the arrangement of the program, according to William B.
Kempton, chairman of the committee.

The debating team will debate with
the University of Cincinnati next
Thursday in room 205, Gilman Hall,
it was announced last week by Abner
Willen, president of the Debating
Council.
The Hopkins team will uphold the
affirmative tide of the question "Resolved, That the nations of the world
shall agree to prohibit the international shipment of arms and munitions." This question was debated
several weeks ago by members of
the Debating Council.
Those who will argue for the affirmative are Sylvan Garfunkel, Philip
Grossman and Abner Willen.
The annual southern trip taken by
the team will begin March 25, the
first debate being with the University
of North Carolina. The team will
then go to Emory College, Oglethorpe
University, and the University I of
Georgia. The trip will end about
April 1 with a debate against the
University of South Carolina.
The northern trip will be taken
about the same time with two debates
almost assured. Temple, University
and LaSalle University will pit teams
against the Hopkins debaters. Those
who will make this trip are James
Morrow, Phillip Grossman, Neal Potter, and Paul Zucker. Abner Willen
and Sylvan Garfunkel will represent
the Hopkins on the southern trip.
The debating team engaged Mt. St.
Mary's last night at Emittsburg.
Those who debated for the University
team were Paul Umbarger, Phillip
Grossman, Paul Zucker, and James
Morrow.

Our Own Pepys
February 26—
Up and amused by Mr. Edward
Reilly's remarks at a meeting to
raise funds for the appeal of the case
of Bruno Hauptman.
"I defy anyone to prove that Hauptman was even in New Jersey the
night of the kidnapping," said Reilly.
This I cannot help but feel to be a
trifle anti-climactic, the point in question having been for all practical
purposes very effectively demonstrated some few weeks back.
So away to the University for a
little, where I met with Paul who
told me that he was no longer in
love, that his ideals had been shattered, that his faith in human nature
was now a negative quantity, but
that the affair with all had been a
very •broadening experience. It was
with the greatest of difficulty'that I
explained my uncontrolable mirth at
his remarks, my own faith in human
nature, etc., having been at a very
low ebb for some time past.
I to the library for some reading
in the mechanistic and vitalistic approaches to biological phenomena
(which topic is obviously introduced
into these pages to show the extent
and magnitude of my learning).
Reading is to serve as the basis for a
debate on the subject. I am utterly
deficient in biological knowledge, but
as my fellow debater, W. D., has been
assured by a most eminent professor
of the subject, that this is an asset
and not a debit, I shall not let it
trouble me.
Interrupted by Leon bearing proudly two front pages of the American
Weekly of some time back which, he
explained, were the gift of a learned
archaeologist. I found the association
of archaelogy with Mr. Heart's journal somewhat incongrous, but did not
mention my feeling to Leon for fear
of offending him.
So home, and to bed early to escape the talk of a friend of the family. He is the °illy man of my acquaintance in the State who can carry on

having been born in his present senility.

"KATIE, THE KITZBUEHEL COQUETTE"—The return of the Prince
of Wales to England after a vacation
abroad was the occasion for the introduction of many new songs
throughout Britain. It so happened
that the heir to the British throne
had spent his holiday in Austria, Germany, Hungary, and France, particularly at Kitzbuehel.

By HAROLD M. KROPMAN

One song in particular "I'm Katie,
the Kitzbuehel Coquette" bids fair to
become one of Britain's most popular
songs, though not meant to reflect on
England's fair sex.

the end of a very successful season,
I think it is only just and proper to
see exactly who has been responsible
for all the terrible—hard work. There
is Carson Frailey, president, who
hates the noise of bombs and dice;
John Murphy, vice-president, who
thinks the most of wine, women, and
song as evidenced by his behavior on
the Atlantic City trip; Lou Reuling,
junior business manager, who leans
toward crooning as an art and accomplishment; and Harry Beck, business manager, who always makes the
announcements to the NEWS-LETTER.

Lilly To Address
Counseling Class
Athletic Director At Polytechnic Will
Speak To Afternoon Group; Night
Class To Hear Baer

;

:.:e.p.•:;:•:•:•

At the regular meeting of the class
in camp counseling to be held tomorrow at 4.15 p. m. in Gilman 312, William S. Lilly III, director of athletics
at the Baltimore Polytechnic Institute, will be the speaker.
The night class will be addressed
by Reuben Baer, head of the counseling course, who will speak on "The
Counselor." The class will take place
at 7 p. in. in Gilman 205. Visitors are
welcome.

Aviation Club Plans To
Reorganize Completely
A complete reorganization of club
program and activities will be effected at the next meeting ef the
Aviation Club to be held Wednesday,
March 6, at 4 p. m. in the Student
Activities office.
During the meeting Grahame Duce,
president of the club, will present for
examination 150 photos of hereto unphotographed United States military
aircraft. All members are urged to
attend the meeting.
